title: 114_s1639
content: The Act titled "Education Stability for Foster Youth Act" aims to provide educational stability for foster children. The Education Stability for Foster Youth Act requires State Plans to ensure collaboration between State educational and social agencies to maintain educational stability for children in foster care. The Education Stability for Foster Youth Act requires immediate enrollment in a new school if it is not in the best interest of the child to remain in their current school. The enrolling school must contact the child's previous school for relevant records. The State educational agency must designate a point of contact for child welfare agencies to oversee implementation of agency responsibilities. Local plans under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 are amended to include additional requirements. The Education Stability for Foster Youth Act requires collaboration between the State or local child welfare agency to develop clear procedures for providing transportation to maintain children in foster care in their school of origin. The Education Stability for Foster Youth Act mandates collaboration between child welfare and educational agencies to provide transportation for foster children to stay in their original schools, with reimbursement agreements in place. The Education Stability for Foster Youth Act requires collaboration between child welfare and educational agencies for transportation costs, with reimbursement agreements in place. The Education Stability for Foster Youth Act mandates a report on the implementation of educational stability for children in foster care, including progress and barriers. Additionally, it defines a homeless child or youth. The McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act is amended to remove the provision regarding children awaiting foster care placement. The effective date of this amendment is one year after enactment, except for covered States where it applies two years after enactment.
